title: chore: fix impl_trait_overcaptures warning for edition 2024
body:
#### Problem
Migration to Edition 2024 (https://github.com/anza-xyz/agave/issues/6203) changes semantics of capturing references.
Warnings reported by [impl_trait_overcaptures](https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/nightly-rustc/rustc_lint/impl_trait_overcaptures/static.IMPL_TRAIT_OVERCAPTURES.html) highlight the changed behavior, fixing them isn't strictly necessary for using edition 2024, however given small number and diff for them it's reasonable to fix and deny them.

#### Summary of Changes
* Add use<..> annotations for returned impl types
* add `impl_trait_overcaptures` to workspace denied warnings

v3.2.0

What's Changed

v3.1.1

What's Changed

  • Fix async test functions inside a serial mod block in palfrey/serial_test#111

Full Changelog: https://github.com/palfrey/serial_test/compare/v3.1.0...v3.1.1

v3.1.0

What's Changed

  • Replace lazy_static with once_cell by @​Expyron in palfrey/serial_test#106
  • Replace dashmap with scc by @​palfrey in palfrey/serial_test#109
  • Standard test attribute worked with mod, others didn't (e.g. tokio::test) by @​palfrey in palfrey/serial_test#110

New Contributors

  • @​Expyron made their first contribution in palfrey/serial_test#106

Full Changelog: https://github.com/palfrey/serial_test/compare/v3.0.0...v3.1.0

v3.0.0

What's Changed

  • Multi key support palfrey/serial_test#102
    • Attributes like #[serial(one, two)] are now supported (for all attributes)
    • This is a breaking change, as file_serial paths now need to be done separately #[file_serial(key, path => "/tmp/foo")]
  • Attributes at a mod-level palfrey/serial_test#104
    • You can set any of the attributes on a mod and all #[test] fn's in that mod will have the attribute applied.

title: Remove accounts-db append_vec bench
body:
#### Problem
Use of stable toolchain (same as for production code) for all codebase is much preferred to using nightly. To achieve that it's necessary switch benchmarks to use one of the benchmarking frameworks that works in stable - criterion / bencher.
However benchmarks that have high runtime variance cause those frameworks to increase number of iterations significantly making total bench runtime unbearable. This is also a sign the benches are not useful.

In case of append_vec it tests IO performance plus does some checks that test correctness, not useful either as a benchmark.

#### Summary of Changes
Remove append_vec bench. See also discussion in https://github.com/anza-xyz/agave/pull/8934

#### Problem

We want to update to rust 2024 edition (see #6203). But until then, we could still add 2024-incompatible code.


#### Summary of Changes
* Add lints to the new fs crate for rust 2024
* Fix temporary value scope
* Remove unnecessary `ref mut` bindings
* Quote `gen` symbol
* Add `use<>`

(This is based on Brooks' draft https://github.com/anza-xyz/agave/pull/8915)

title: Uses ahash in Bucket::bucket_index_ix()
body:
#### Problem `Bucket::bucket_index_ix()` shows up in slowlana perf profiles as taking a non-negligible amount of time at startup. Most of the time is spent hashing. Note that we call `Bucket::bucket_index_ix()` every time we access the disk index, not just at startup. So it is in our best interest to make this as fast as possible. Currently, we use the rust default hasher, which is SipHash 1-3. But, we just a default instance of the hasher... so it kinda defeats the purpose of using a secure hasher like SipHash. This observation implies we actually want a stable hash, thus SipHash is not necessary, and a faster hasher can be used instead.
slowlana - master

Here's the call tree, showing that `bucket_index_ix()` currently uses ~5%: And here's the flamegraph showing the same:

#### Summary of Changes Use ahash instead.
slowlana - pr

Here's the call tree showing that `bucket_index_ix()` now only takes ~0.6%: And here's the flamegraph showing the same:

Another anecdotal comparison: I ran ledger-tool with a mnb snapshot on my dev box and saw that this PR finished building the accounts index slightly faster each time. When starting from no existing disk index files, master took ~48 seconds, and with this PR took ~46 seconds. There's probably some variation in there. More sharing to indicate we haven't caused some regression either.

title: Removes extra startup accounts index flush threads
body: #### Problem At startup, when the accounts disk index is enabled, we spin up another set of background threads to flush index entries to disk. These extra threads no longer are beneficial. Note also that we also have num_cores-worth of threads for generating the index (scanning the storages, computing the lt hash), so all additional threads may be stealing resources. In the image (of master) above we can see a few things: 1. The num_cores-worth of threads for generating the index. I.e. `solGenIndex63` 2. The `solIdxFlusher` threads, and the duplicates/extra 3. The large time gaps where the flusher threads are not busy 4. Dips in the `solGenIndex` threads while the flusher threads are busy -- I believe this indicates cpu resource contention, and the flushing stealing from generating the index. 5. The highlighted line, on `wait_timeout`, which is 8.1% #### Summary of Changes Remove the extra startup flush threads. On my dev box I compared this PR to master for startup time, on mnb, and noticed that master finished building the index in 30-32 seconds, whereas this PR took 28-30 seconds. So this PR was a bit faster, anecdotally. May be attributed by lower resource contention, or just per run variation. Here's the slowlana profile of this PR. Note: 1. Extra threads are no longer present 2. Non-busy gaps in the flusher threads are reduced 3. The highlighted line, on `wait_timeout`, has reduced to 1.2%

title: refactor: rename the `VerifiedVote` channel types
body:
#### Problem
`VerifiedVoteSender` and `VerifiedVoteReceiver` are poorly named.  The channels are not sending verified votes but actually sending information the slots in which a voter voted and that was verified.  This type and the associated variable names in the code cause quite a bit of confusion.

#### Summary of Changes

- renames `VerifiedVoteSender` to `VerifiedVoterSender`
- renames `VerifiedVoteReceiver` to `VerifiedVoterReceiver`
- renames the associated variables

I know generally speaking renaming stuff is bad practice as it can makes it harder to parse git history.  I hope this change will still be accepted as it has caused me confusion more than once.  And a bunch of the code in this space is in flux due to the ongoing work on Alpenglow and repair.

title: Update xtask version to 0.1.0 since we will never publish the xtask crate

labels.name: v3.1
labels.description: Backport to v3.1 branch

body:
### Problem
The version bump PRs increment the xtask crate version. we don't publish that crate so there's no need to increment the version number, and doing so clutters the version bumps.

## Solution
Revert xtask version to 0.1.0.

title: alpenglow: upstream block_creation_loop
body:
#### Problem
Alpenglow uses a different process to create leader blocks, instead of having replay insert new banks we spin up a separate loop. This will also replace PohService.

#### Summary of Changes
Create a new loop that only starts when PohService is shutdown. It receives notifications from votor to produce our window and then inserts and clears the banks in our window

In a future PR we will actually plug this into the validator for use when migration is successful. Follow up PR will also add detailed metrics for things in this loop.

title: Removes bucket-map benches
body:
#### Problem

Benchmarks that use the old nightly bencher are a pain.


#### Summary of Changes

For the bucket-map crate, the benchmarks are not useful IMO.

* They benchmark the bucket map vs a hashmap, which seems questionably useful. Maybe when this code was first written it was useful to see a ballpark number for perf.
* Benchmarking file IO is hard. Are we just actually benchmarking the file system/disk? Is everything cached by the kernel and thus not benchmarking anything? It's hard to say.
* These benchmarks were added with the initial add of the bucket-map crate, and I think have never been looked at since.

So we don't actually use them, combined with they are of questionable value. Let's remove them.

title: Refactor: consumer tests
body:
#### Problem
- Many tests were written long ago and use same setup but repeat the code
- Other tests are testing that other components (TransactionStatusService, Blockstore) work as they should. This is not what unit-tests are for.

#### Summary of Changes
- Refactor most tests to use a shared setup
- Change integration tests to check messages passed over the status channel instead of the behavior of tss and blockstore.

Fixes #
<!-- OPTIONAL: Feature Gate Issue: # -->
<!-- Don't forget to add the "feature-gate" label -->

title: clippy: remove unused log::* import
body:
#### Problem
Newer rust toolchains detect that * imports are unused and `log::*` gets flagged.

#### Summary of Changes
Remove unused import.

title: clippy: Address mut_from_ref instances
body:
#### Problem
https://github.com/anza-xyz/agave/issues/6850

Running `clippy` with Rust 1.88.0 yields the following:
```
error: mutable borrow from immutable input(s)
   --> syscalls/src/lib.rs:586:13
    |
586 | ) -> Result<&'a mut T, Error> {
    |             ^^^^^^^^^
    |
note: immutable borrow here
   --> syscalls/src/lib.rs:583:21
    |
583 |     memory_mapping: &'a MemoryMapping,
    |                     ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
    = help: for further information visit https://rust-lang.github.io/rust-clippy/master/index.html#mut_from_ref
    = note: `#[deny(clippy::mut_from_ref)]` on by default
```

#### Summary of Changes
Apply a `#[allow(clippy::mut_from_ref)]` guard to these two function. As @Lichtso responded below:

> Clippy does not understand that address comes from an u64, nof a reference. Also, changing the mapped data does not influence the mapping.

Progress towards https://github.com/anza-xyz/agave/issues/6850 (intermediate goal) and https://github.com/anza-xyz/agave/issues/8894 (end goal)

title: clippy: Address clone_ref_to_slice_refs instances
body:
#### Problem
We want to advance to Rust 1.89.0; running `clippy` with 1.89.0 yields the following:
```
error: this call to `clone` can be replaced with `std::slice::from_ref`
   --> tests/programs.rs:882:13
    |
882 |             &[invoked_program_id.clone()],
    |             ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ help: try: `std::slice::from_ref(&invoked_program_id)`
    |
    = help: for further information visit https://rust-lang.github.io/rust-clippy/master/index.html#cloned_ref_to_slice_refs
    = note: `-D clippy::cloned-ref-to-slice-refs` implied by `-D warnings`
    = help: to override `-D warnings` add `#[allow(clippy::cloned_ref_to_slice_refs)]`
```

#### Summary of Changes
Apply the suggested change; progress towards https://github.com/anza-xyz/agave/issues/8894

title: Refactor: external worker separate channel from struct
body:
#### Problem
- Was using unsafe `try_read_ptr` then immediately `as_ref`-ing. We can use the safe alternative.

#### Summary of Changes
- Use `try_read` instead of `try_read_ptr`
- To get around borrow-checker, separated receiver from the rest of the struct

Fixes #

body:
#### Problem
- `tpu_to_pack` was written before `try_write` interface stabilized
- Can use the safe altnerative

#### Summary of Changes
- Refactor to use try_write in tpu_to_pack

Fixes #

title: clippy: Address manual_let_else instances
body:
#### Problem
Rust 1.89 clippy doesn't like this block:
```
--> cli/src/main.rs:27:13

27 | /             let config_file = match matches.value_of("config_file") {
28 | |                 None => {
29 | |                     println!(
30 | |                         "{} Either provide the `--config` arg or ensure home directory exists to \
...  |
36 | |                 Some(config_file) => config_file,
37 | |             };
   | |______________^

= help: for further information visit https://rust-lang.github.io/rust-clippy/master/index.html#manual_let_else
```
#### Summary of Changes
Apply the suggestion:
```
= note: requested on the command line with `-D clippy::manual-let-else`
help: consider writing

27 ~             let Some(config_file) = matches.value_of("config_file") else {
28 +                     println!(
29 +                         "{} Either provide the `--config` arg or ensure home directory exists to \
30 +                          use the default config location",
31 +                         style("No config file found.").bold()
32 +                     );
33 +                     return Ok(false);
34 +                 };
```

Work towards resolving https://github.com/anza-xyz/agave/issues/8894

title: chore: Address mismatched_lifetime_syntaxes warnings
body:
#### Problem
The following warning is present when running with Rust 1.89.0:
```
error: lifetime flowing from input to output with different syntax can be confusing
  --> cost-model/benches/cost_tracker.rs:47:19
   |
47 |     transactions: &[WritableKeysTransaction],
   |                   ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ this lifetime flows to the output
48 | ) -> Vec<TransactionCost<WritableKeysTransaction>> {
   |          ---------------------------------------- the lifetime gets resolved as `'_`
   |
   = note: `-D mismatched-lifetime-syntaxes` implied by `-D warnings`
   = help: to override `-D warnings` add `#[allow(mismatched_lifetime_syntaxes)]`
help: one option is to remove the lifetime for references and use the anonymous lifetime for paths
   |
48 | ) -> Vec<TransactionCost<'_, WritableKeysTransaction>> {
   |                          +++
```

#### Summary of Changes
Apply the suggested change to the two relevant locations.

Part of https://github.com/anza-xyz/agave/issues/8894

title: chore: Avoid dangerous-implicit-autoref
body:
#### Problem
Rust 1.88 raises this as a warning and suggests using a raw pointer method to to make the reference explicit. 

#### Summary of Changes
We need a reference to call function like .len(), so make the reference intentional. Without this, we get the following warning:
```
error: implicit autoref creates a reference to the dereference of a raw pointer
   --> transaction-context/src/transaction_accounts.rs:465:13
    |
465 | /             (*self.shared_account_fields.get())
466 | |                 .get(index as usize)
    | |____________________________________^
    |
    = note: creating a reference requires the pointer target to be valid and imposes aliasing requirements
    = note: `-D dangerous-implicit-autorefs` implied by `-D warnings`
    = help: to override `-D warnings` add `#[allow(dangerous_implicit_autorefs)]`
help: try using a raw pointer method instead; or if this reference is intentional, make it explicit
    |
465 |             (&(*self.shared_account_fields.get()))
    |             ++                                   +
```
There is no change in behavior in this PR as far as I can tell; we were getting references before and still are. So, the safety warning that are present in the adjacent lines are presumed to still be correct

Progress towards https://github.com/anza-xyz/agave/issues/6850 (intermediate goal) and https://github.com/anza-xyz/agave/issues/8894 (end goal)

title: test: only activate direct mapping with stricter ABI constraints enabled
body:
#### Problem
Some tests and helpers are activating direct mapping without `stricter_abi_and_runtime_constraints`. This potentially masks undesired behavior in tests as the feature activation ordering isn't planned to have direct mapping without first activating `stricter_abi_and_runtime_constraints`.

#### Summary of Changes
Disable direct mapping in tests that disable `stricter_abi_and_runtime_constraints`.

Optionally, `FeatureSet::deactivate` could be aware of dependent features to prevent regressions or debug assertions could be added `debug_assert!(!direct_mapping || stricter_abi_and_runtime_constraints)`

cc @Lichtso 
<!-- OPTIONAL: Feature Gate Issue: # -->
<!-- Don't forget to add the "feature-gate" label -->

title: net-utils: remove deprecated v3.* functions and types
body:
Remove all deprecated functions and types from solana-net-utils that were
  marked for deprecation since v3.0.0.

  ## Problem

  The `solana-net-utils` crate contains deprecated functions and types that were marked for deprecation since v3.0.0. These
  need to be removed as part of the codebase cleanup effort.

  ## Summary of Changes

  Removed 15 deprecated functions, 1 deprecated struct, and their associated tests from the solana-net-utils crate:

  **From lib.rs:**
  - Removed `get_public_ip_addr()` function
  - Removed `SocketConfig` struct and its implementation
  - Removed 11 socket binding functions that are now available in `sockets::SocketConfiguration`
  - Removed 1 test that used deprecated types

  **From sockets.rs:**
  - Removed deprecated `bind_with_any_port_with_config()` function
  - Removed private `_bind_with_any_port_with_config()` workaround
  - Removed `From<SocketConfig>` trait implementation

  Fixes #8900

title: v3.1: suppress erroneous lints related to nested deprecation blocks (backport of #8899)
body:
#### Problem
after introduction of `agave-unstable-api` in #8424, developer workflows that involved building single crates from within their containing directories began to raise deprecation lints, despite dependencies being appropriately declared. this appears to be an issue with cargo related to nested deprecation blocks as all instances were on previously deprecated symbols within now globaly deprecated crates.

#### Summary of Changes
apply deprecation allowances on the smallest effective context

---

this is a backportable stopgap as many of the effected locations were long past due for removal  and those that weren't are now since master is on 4.0<hr>This is an automatic backport of pull request #8899 done by [Mergify](https://mergify.com).

title: Enable Obsolete Accounts by default
body: #### Problem - Obsolete accounts that has extensive bench testing (ran for 60+ days, unit tests, snapshot tests etc... ), and is ready to get tested more widely. #### Summary of Changes - Switch tests to mark obsolete accounts by default - Change the default feature value to enabled - Reconfigure the CLI switch to take in an enable/disable parameter rather than a flag to enable #### Current Timing Benefits Note that in all graphs: Blue = feature enabled validator, orange/purple = mce validators ~ 10% reduced incremental snapshot size 75% reduced time cleaning #### Current Non-TIming Benefits - Squash can make smarter decisions as there are no dependencies between different storage files - Full Snapshots saved on nodes that do not perform database scans for RPC will only have a single copy of each account #### Future benefits - Shrink optimizations reducing complexity, write rate and time spent shrinking Fixes #

title: feat(scheduler-bindings): huge pages; queue sizes in items
body:
#### Problem

- Allocators and queues could benefit from huge pages if available but currently do not take advantage of them.
- Queue sizes in bytes are confusing to users trying to set a minimum message capacity.

#### Summary of Changes

- First try to map using huge pages, falling back to regular pages on failure.
- Specify queues sizes in terms of messages, this also makes it easier to manage the page alignment requirements.

title: Simplify ListViewIter with ChunksExact
body:
#### Problem
`ListViewIter` performs manual bookkeeping with `index` and `rev_index` to manage progress through the iterator. `Iterator` and `DoubleEndedIterator` implementations only consider `index` and `rev_index`, respectively, which leads to incorrect iteration when using both `next` and `next_back` on the same iterator.

Additionally, `next` and `next_back` perform a bounds check before calling `view.item(index)`, which performs its own bound checking, resulting in duplicated bounds checks on each iteration.

#### Summary of Changes

This refactors `ListViewIter` to hold a `std::slice::ChunksExact`, which efficiently implements the manual bookkeeping that is currently in use by shrinking its internal slice on each iteration. This makes `Iterator` and `DoubleEndedIterator` implementations trivial, as they simply delegate iterator progress to `std::slice::ChunksExact` and perform the read on the byte chunk. This also gives us the optimized implementations for `count`, `size_hint`, `nth`, and `last` for free.

Also included tests, which exercise this behavior. Current implementation fails the tests that exercise `next` and `next_back` together.

title: Deprecates `--accounts-db-access-storages-method mmap`
body:
#### Problem

Mmap-ing in general should be avoided for performance. We currently allow using mmaps for append vec storage access.


#### Summary of Changes

Historically, we've still allowed mmap because RPCs saw perf regressions when using file-io. After talking with RPCs running v3.0, they have said the perf regressions using file-io are now gone.

Deprecate `--accounts-db-access-storages-method mmap`.

title: v3.1: Implement size_hint for ListViewIter (backport of #8866)
body:
#### Problem `ListViewIter` doesn't implement `size_hint`, which means building collections from it can't preallocate destination memory. This is part of the `collect_vote_lockouts` perf improvements. https://github.com/anza-xyz/agave/blob/3e7bb4a162422552a95c7d5a444564a9428f5d75/core/src/consensus.rs#L428 `TowerVoteState::from` builds its internal `VecDeque` from `ListViewIter`, which as stated above cannot preallocate due to lack of a `size_hint`. This accounts for roughly 25% of execution time: #### Summary of Changes This implements `size_hint` for `ListViewIter` so that creating collections from it can properly preallocate.
This is an automatic backport of pull request #8866 done by [Mergify](https://mergify.com).

title: feat(scheduler-bindings): add flag to reroute votes to external scheduler
body:
#### Problem

- External schedulers may wish to ensure they can build blocks deterministically. An internal vote worker prevents this while votes and user transactions share resource caps.

#### Summary of Changes

- Allow the external scheduler to specify when they wish to manage vote transactions.

title: feat(scheduler-bindings): add drop on failure & all or nothing flags
body:
#### Problem

- External schedulers may want to only commit transactions that execute successfully or they may use batches as atomic blocks.

#### Summary of Changes

- Let external schedulers set `drop_on_failure` or `all_or_nothing` flags.

title: Implement size_hint for ListViewIter

labels.name: v3.1
labels.description: Backport to v3.1 branch

body: #### Problem `ListViewIter` doesn't implement `size_hint`, which means building collections from it can't preallocate destination memory. This is part of the `collect_vote_lockouts` perf improvements. https://github.com/anza-xyz/agave/blob/3e7bb4a162422552a95c7d5a444564a9428f5d75/core/src/consensus.rs#L428 `TowerVoteState::from` builds its internal `VecDeque` from `ListViewIter`, which as stated above cannot preallocate due to lack of a `size_hint`. This accounts for roughly 25% of execution time: #### Summary of Changes This implements `size_hint` for `ListViewIter` so that creating collections from it can properly preallocate.

title: Optimize LockoutIntervals in collect_vote_lockouts

labels.name: v3.1
labels.description: Backport to v3.1 branch

body: #### Problem `collect_vote_lockouts` is a major bottleneck in replay stage. Problem as it relates to this PR: `LockoutIntervals` is represented as a `BTreeMap>`. This is extremely slow as we create `num_slots` non-contiguous nodes with each containing its own separate `Vec` allocation, neither of which can be preallocated. The result is significant heap churn and pointer chasing. 43.7% of the time is spent building `LockoutIntervals`: #### Summary of Changes This PR replaces `BTreeMap>` with a flat, preallocated `Vec` containing: ```rs pub struct LockoutInterval { pub voter: Pubkey, pub start: VotedSlot, pub end: ExpirationSlot, } ``` The downstream code, `make_check_switch_threshold_decision`, simply filters on `end`, preserving the existing behavior. The result is that populating `LockoutIntervals` now accounts for around 21.7% of execution time, nearly cutting total execution time in half.

title: Optimize HashMap/HashSet usage in collect_vote_lockouts

labels.name: v3.1
labels.description: Backport to v3.1 branch

body: #### Problem `collect_vote_lockouts` is a major bottleneck in replay stage. A few problems as it relates to this PR: `collect_vote_lockouts` uses a `HashSet` and `HashMap` for recording voted slots and voted stakes, respectively. - Default `HashMap` and `HashSet` use siphash, which is unnecessary given that we don't need dos resistance or hash persistence - The `HashSet` is ephemeral and dynamically allocated on every invocation of `collect_vote_lockouts` - We record vote slots that fall outside the fork root, which creates unnecessary churn in both `vote_slots` and `vote_stakes` We spend 9.4% of of time in `vote_stakes.entry` and 12% of time in `vote_slots.insert` #### Summary of Changes - `vote_slots` and `vote_stakes` now use `AHashSet` and `AHashMap` - `vote_slots` is reused between invocations - `vote_slots` is pre-reserved using `bank_slot - min_ancestor_of(bank_slot)` - `vote_slots` only records slots that fall within the fork root - we avoid creating needless `Lockout` structs just to record slots `vote_stakes.entry` improved 3.5x `vote_slots.insert` improved 4.2x

title: remove `solana-stake-program`
body:
#### Problem
#7203 removed all usage of the native stake program itself in the agave codebase, switching the builtin to bpf stake, pulling the core bpf repo for genesis, and using a bpf stake binary for tests. #7645 deleted the native stake program implementation, in other words virtually all stake program code

to keep the enormous diff of #7645 trivial, we left behind a few utility functions that were used in other parts of the codebase. this pr removes `solana-stake-program` entirely

#### Summary of Changes
* everything in `points.rs` was already copied to runtime by someone other than myself. this is deleted with no additions
* `config.rs` and `epoch_rewards.rs` only exist to set up these accounts for genesis. this functionality is moved to `runtime::genesis_utils` since it is lowest on the dependency tree compared to `genesis` and `genesis-utils`
* `stake_state.rs` deserialization wrappers are mostly deleted and replaced with standard deserialize calls. a few are moved where they are used frequently and locally
* `stake_state::create_account()` is moved to a new `runtime::stake_utils` module. this is used in many places, the logic is very annoying, and it is only required for tests and cli so it shouldnt be added to stake interface. it is also copy-pasted to `accounts-db` behind dcou, the one place that cannot import runtime
* `get_minimum_delegation()` is also added to `runtime::stake_utils`. this is a trivial function that accepts a bool and returns 1 or 1*10^9. the main reason to keep it is that when we implement minimum delegation (under a new feature flag), this marks the places in agave that care about it
* switch anything that was getting structs, program id, etc from `solana-stake-program` to `solana-stake-interface`
* delete `solana-stake-program` in its entirety

#### Upgrade Path
after this lands, we will be free to reuse the `solana-stake-program` name on crates io for the bpf stake program

our timing here is actually impeccable. native stake reexports stake interface, so removing it is a major breaking change for downstream. but the entire package was marked unstable in agave 3.x, and master is now on 4.0 alpha. this means we can land this pr _now_ with no issues

bpf stake is presently on 1.0, with a version bump (to 2.0 or 1.1 im not sure) planned. after this pr lands, we must skip bpf stake **at least to 4.0** and then we can push to crates io. if any 4.x agave release hits crates io before this pr is merged, we should skip bpf stake to 5.0
